arm_group.description: emergency radiotherapy within 12 hours after neurological deficit due to MSCC

brief_summary.textblock:
Acute neurological deficit in metastatic spinal cord compression is an emergency condition
      in radiation oncology.  Despite some reports about the high efficacy of radiation treatment
      for oncological emergencies, a standard of care is not well defined, especially the time
      interval of immediate RT after deficit, and neurological outcome with respect to poor
      survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients. The objective of this trial is to
      investigate neurological outcome after emergency radiotherapy in metastatic spinal cord
      compression of non-small cell lung cancer patients with acute neurological deficit.

clinical_study.brief_title: Emergency Radiotherapy in Metastatic Spinal Cord Compression of Patients With Non-small Cell Lung Cancer
condition: Survival From First Diagnosis Metastatic Spinal Cord Compression to Death

detailed_description.textblock:
Subjects and recruitment 15 consecutive patients with histologically confirmed non-small
      cell lung cancer and bone metastases of the thoracic or lumbar segments of the vertebral
      column will be screened for this trial in the Radiooncology Department of the Heidelberg
      University Clinic. Inclusion criteria are an age of 18 to 80 years, acute neurological
      symptom caused by metastatic spinal cord compression, no radiotherapy in this spinal area
      before, and written consent to participate.

      Design and procedures This is a prospective, controlled, explorative trial to investigate
      the neurological outcome after emergency radiotherapy in metastatic spinal cord compression
      of non-small cell lung cancer patients with acute neurological deficit. RT start within 12
      hours after onset of neurological symptoms. The target parameters will be measured at the
      start of radiotherapy (t0), and six weeks after radiotherapy (RT) (t1). The target
      parameters comprise the documentation and completion of the ASIA Impairment Scale (AIS), and
      the recording of patient-specific data.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Inclusion criteria are an age of 18 to 80 years, acute neurological symptom caused by
             metastatic spinal cord compression, no RT in this spinal area before, and written
             consent to participate.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  neurological symptom more than 12 hours before

study_pop.textblock:
histologically confirmed non-small cell lung cancer and bone metastases of the thoracic or
        lumbar segments of the vertebral column

facility.name: University hospital of Heidelberg, Departement radiation oncology

clinical_study.official_title: Phase 1 Study of Neurological Outcome After Emergency Radiotherapy in Metastatic Spinal Cord Compression

primary_outcome.description: The primary endpoint was neurological outcome, assessed using the ASIA Impairment Scale (AIS)

reference.citation: Rades D, Fehlauer F, Schulte R, Veninga T, Stalpers LJ, Basic H, Bajrovic A, Hoskin PJ, Tribius S, Wildfang I, Rudat V, Engenhart-Cabilic R, Karstens JH, Alberti W, Dunst J, Schild SE. Prognostic factors for local control and survival after radiotherapy of metastatic spinal cord compression. J Clin Oncol. 2006 Jul 20;24(21):3388-93.

Bach F, Larsen BH, Rohde K, Børgesen SE, Gjerris F, Bøge-Rasmussen T, Agerlin N, Rasmusson B, Stjernholm P, Sørensen PS. Metastatic spinal cord compression. Occurrence, symptoms, clinical presentations and prognosis in 398 patients with spinal cord compression. Acta Neurochir (Wien). 1990;107(1-2):37-43.

Christian E, Adamietz IA, Willich N, Schäfer U, Micke O; German Working Group Palliative Radiotherapy; German Society for Radiation Oncology (DEGRO). Radiotherapy in oncological emergencies--final results of a patterns of care study in Germany, Austria and Switzerland. Acta Oncol. 2008;47(1):81-9.
